name: APPLE II+
ram: 48 KB (64 KB max. with language card)
ports: Composite monitor, Internal Slots (8),  Tape recorder In/Out jacks
description:
The Apple II+ was the successor to the Apple II.

It was fully compatible with the Apple II. It, however, had new features:

- a new ROM holding the AppleSoft Basic (floating point version written by Microsoft),
- a new auto-start (stored in ROM) for easier start-up and screen editing,
- 48 KB RAM,
- text modes were the same as the Apple II, but the graphics modes were enhanced, they're the same as the Apple 2e : 16 colours at low resolution and 6 colours at high resolutions. In fact this 6-colour mode was also available on the Apple II since revision 1 of the motherboard. 

The Apple II+ was sold in Europe as the Apple IIeuroplus which could display video in European PAL format, and had ESC sequences for European letters. It was followed by the Apple 2e.

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> TOP VIEW</strong></font><br><blockquote>The II+ had the same case and keyboard as the Apple ][</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPLETE SYSTEM</strong></font><br><blockquote>With Monitor II and dual Disk II floppy drive units</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>The keyboard card is located below the keyboard.<br> A 16 KB RAM expansion card is inserted in the slot 0. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>From left to right:<br> • Composite video output jack<br> • Tape recorder In/Out jacks<br> • Power socket and switch</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MAINBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>The mainboard is nearly the same as the Apple II version.<br><br> <b><font color="blue">(1)</font></b> 8 expansion slots<br> <b><font color="blue">(2)</font></b> 6502 microprocessor<br> <b><font color="blue">(3)</font></b> 6 ROMs of 2 KB each, containing the AppleSoft BASIC interpreter and I/O routines<br> <b><font color="blue">(4)</font></b> 48 KB RAM chips in 3 banks of 8 x 4116. The white socket is used to connect a RAM extension card inserted in slot 0<br> <b><font color="blue">(5)</font></b> Keyboard connector<br> <b><font color="blue">(6)</font></b> Video and tape recorder circuitry. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> CLOSE-UP #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>RAM banks. Notice that each bank holds RAM chips of different brand names.</blockquote>

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, OCT. 1981</strong></font><br><blockquote>From Personal Computing, October 1981.<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of '<a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a>'</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, APRIL 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote>From Personal Computing, April 1982<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT OCT 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Apple hardware advertisement.<br> From Personal Computing, October 1983 issue<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> METACARD AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>The MetaCard was the first card allowing an Apple II owner to run IBM-PC programs and MS-DOS, CPM/86 and UCSD operating systems.<br> It used a 5 MHz. 8088 processor, 64 to 128 KB of RAM and a dedicated powed supply unit.<br><br> It was priced at <b>$980</b> (64KB version) and <b>$1,150</b> (128 KB). </blockquote>

item.description: Workstation Card |||Appletalk card|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> WORKSTATION CARD </strong></font><br><strong>> Appletalk card</strong><br><blockquote>This card is used to connect an Apple IIe to a localtalk network. </blockquote>

Z80 Softcard advert||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> Z80 SOFTCARD ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Z80 Softcard made the Apple II fully compatible with the CP/M operating system and allowed it to run the largest library of professional software of the time, including the Microsoft programming languages, among them the  BASIC 5.0 interpreter. </blockquote>

Z80 SoftCard|||Full package|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> Z80 SOFTCARD</strong></font><br><strong>> Full package</strong><br><blockquote>The card was designed by Burtronix of Orange, California. <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Steve Perry</b></p></blockquote>

Microsoft Ramcard advert (1982)||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> MICROSOFT RAMCARD ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Together with the Softcard, the Ramcard turned the Apple II into a 56 KB CP/M system.</blockquote>

Joysticks||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> JOYSTICKS</strong></font><br><blockquote>Two Apple joysticks for IIe and IIc versions, and a clone version with a fire button made by CH Products, San Marco, California.</blockquote>

Dynatyper||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> DYNATYPER</strong></font><br><blockquote>Here is the sale brochure of the Dynatyper, a strange and obscure printing device launched in 1980:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Dynatyper is a new typewriter interface system designed to generate hard copy directly from computer output through any electric typewriter. It exploits the high quality and use of full upper and lower case characters of your electric typewriter. Users of small computer systems can now expand those systems into applications demanding high quality text, such as word processing.<br><br> Consisting of an array of coils positioned in the same pattern as the typewriter's keyboard. These coils are wired into an electrical decoding matrix. Designed to operate on voltage available from standard computers, the Dynatyper is easily installed without modification to your typewriter. Adjustments for different key heights are easy.<br><br> Rochester Data provides interfaces and software for the <b>TRS-80 Level 1 & 2</b>, the <b>Apple II</b> and also a 6 bit <b>parallel interface</b> for general operation with other computers. The same interface board can be modified by jumper selection to eperate in any of the above modes... </font><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Bob Leedom</b> for information and pictures</p></blockquote>
Echo Speech Processor II||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> ECHO SPEECH PROCESSOR II</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

Roland CMU-500 Interface||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> ROLAND CMU-500 INTERFACE</strong></font><br><blockquote>This item, a Roland Compumusic CMU-500 Apple II Interface, was used to connect musical instruments to the Apple II series of computers !</blockquote>
